Block sampling

Source: R/blocksample.R
blocksample.Rd

Sample blockwise from clustered data

blocksample(data, size, idvar = NULL, replace = TRUE, ...)

Arguments

data

Data frame
size

Size of samples
idvar

Column defining the clusters
replace

Logical indicating wether to sample with replacement
...

additional arguments to lower level functions

Value

data.frame

Details

Original id is stored in the attribute 'id'

Examples


d <- data.frame(x=rnorm(5), z=rnorm(5), id=c(4,10,10,5,5), v=rnorm(5))
(dd <- blocksample(d,size=20,~id))
#>               x           z id          v
#> 2    -0.8201687  1.46936229  1 -0.5449456
#> 3     0.3127244 -0.80220037  1  0.9535810

attributes(dd)$id
#>  [1] 10 10  5  5  5  5 10 10 10 10  5  5  4  5  5  5  5  5  5 10 10 10 10  4  5
#> [26]  5  5  5  4  5  5 10 10  5  5  5  5

if (FALSE) {
blocksample(data.table::data.table(d),1e6,~id)
}


d <- data.frame(x=c(1,rnorm(9)),
               z=rnorm(10),
               id=c(4,10,10,5,5,4,4,5,10,5),
               id2=c(1,1,2,1,2,1,1,1,1,2),
               v=rnorm(10))
dsample(d,~id, size=2)
#> Warning: Using formula(x) is deprecated when x is a character vector of length > 1.
#>   Consider formula(paste(x, collapse = " ")) instead.
#>             x           z id id2          v id.1
#> 4   1.4675950  0.08727096  5   1  0.7719504    1
#> 5   0.7284417  0.22424031  5   2 -1.2617650    1
#> 8   0.1311181  0.53218413  5   1 -0.6092151    1
#> 10  0.7818185 -0.01969977  5   2 -0.4098266    1
#> 2  -3.0094030 -1.33914184 10   1 -1.3352669    2
#> 3   0.2706985 -0.02015390 10   2 -0.3334107    2
#> 9  -1.4614550  0.59899580 10   1  0.4814989    2
dsample(d,.~id+id2)
